deliberation: Formulaic prophetic introduction; considered possible personification of 'the word' coming, but in Hebrew this is a standard technical expression functioning as straightforward report of revelation, not as a crafted image in this context.

Looked for covenant-as-marriage imagery and other figures. The core figure is the metaphor of Israel as a young bride devoted to YHWH. The wilderness and unsown land are here historical rather than figurative.

instances.hebrew_text: חֶסֶד נְעוּרַיִךְ אַהֲבַת כְּלוּלֹתָיִךְ לֶכְתֵּךְ אַחֲרַי בַּמִּדְבָּר
instances.english_text: The devotion of your youth, your love as a bride—how you followed Me in the wilderness
target: Israel's early covenant loyalty to YHWH
spiritual relationship of the nation to God
vehicle: a young bride devoted to her husband and following him
ground: exclusive, trusting, eager affection and willingness to follow into hardship
posture: nostalgic, appreciative remembrance of former faithfulness
instances.explanation: Israel's early loyalty in the exodus period is pictured as the love and trust of a newly married bride following her husband into a harsh wilderness.

deliberation: Detected a sustained agricultural/sacrificial metaphor: Israel as consecrated firstfruits of YHWH's harvest that others dare not 'eat'.

instances.hebrew_text: קֹדֶשׁ יִשְׂרָאֵל לַיהוָה רֵאשִׁית תְּבוּאָתֹה כָּל־אֹכְלָיו יֶאְשָׁמוּ
instances.english_text: Israel was holy to the LORD, the first fruits of His harvest. All who ate of it were held guilty
target: Israel as a nation and its protected status
vehicle: holy firstfruits portion of a harvest that is reserved for God and dangerous for others to eat
ground: belonging exclusively to God and bringing guilt on those who misuse it
posture: assertion of Israel's originally sacred and protected status
instances.explanation: Israel is compared to consecrated firstfruits from a harvest, so that foreign powers who 'eat' (attack/exploit) Israel incur guilt before God.

deliberation: Checked for figurative titles and idioms. 'House of Jacob' and 'house of Israel' function as metonymies for the people descended from Jacob/Israel.

instances.hebrew_text: בֵּית יַעֲקֹב ... בֵּית יִשְׂרָאֵל
instances.english_text: House of Jacob ... House of Israel
target: the people of Israel/Judah as a whole
vehicle: a 'house' understood as a family household descended from an ancestor
ground: descent and belonging to a common ancestor
posture: addressing Israel in terms of its ancestral identity
instances.explanation: The term 'house' stands for the descendants of Jacob/Israel; the dwelling metaphorically represents the family line.

deliberation: Focused on 'went after הבל and became הבל'. Here הבל (vapour/vanity) labels idols and their pursuit; people 'walk after' and 'become vain'—a moral/spiritual metaphor.

instances.hebrew_text: וַיֵּלְכוּ אַחֲרֵי הַהֶבֶל וַיֶּהְבָּלוּ
instances.english_text: They went after delusion and were deluded
target: Israel's pursuit of idols and resultant moral character
ground: lack of substance, futility, and self-deception
posture: condemnation of idolatry as futile and self-emptying
instances.explanation: Idolatry is portrayed as chasing 'vanity', so that the pursuers themselves become characterized by the emptiness of what they seek.

deliberation: Examined the wilderness description. The piling up of terms is largely literal, but 'land of צִיָּה וְצַלְמָוֶת' evokes deathly darkness metaphorically, and the double negation 'no man passed, no man dwelt' functions as hyperbolic emphasis on desolation.

instances.hebrew_text: בְּאֶרֶץ צִיָּה וְצַלְמָוֶת
instances.english_text: in a land of drought and darkness (deep shadow of death)
target: the dangerous, threatening character of the wilderness journey
vehicle: a land characterized by desolation and death-shadow
posture: highlighting how God protected Israel in a deathlike environment
instances.explanation: The wilderness is portrayed with imagery of 'death-shadow', emphasizing that it was like a realm of deadly darkness from which God preserved Israel.

instances.hebrew_text: בְּאֶרֶץ לֹא־עָבַר בָּהּ אִישׁ וְלֹא־יָשַׁב אָדָם שָׁם
instances.english_text: a land nobody had traversed, where no human being had dwelt
target: the remoteness and inhospitable nature of the wilderness
degree of human absence and danger
vehicle: a place entirely without travelers or inhabitants
ground: practical impossibility and risk of travel/settlement
posture: emphasizing the extremity of conditions from which God delivered them
instances.explanation: The claim that no one ever passed or lived there overstates the case to stress how desolate and perilous the region was.

deliberation: Looked for metaphorical descriptions of land and sin. 'Defiled my land' and 'made my inheritance an abomination' extend cultic impurity language from ritual to moral/spiritual behavior.

instances.hebrew_text: וַתְּטַמְּאוּ אֶת־אַרְצִי וְנַחֲלָתִי שַׂמְתֶּם לְתוֹעֵבָה
instances.english_text: you defiled My land, you made My possession abhorrent
target: Israel's moral and religious corruption of the land
effects of idolatry and injustice on God's gift
vehicle: ritual impurity and abomination contaminating sacred space
cultic categories of defilement and abomination
ground: that sin makes what should be holy unfit for God's presence
posture: indignant portrayal of their sin as desecrating what is God's
instances.explanation: The people's sins are depicted in cultic terms as ritually defiling God's land and turning His inheritance into something abominable.

deliberation: Considered titles and the description 'after what does not profit.' The key figure here is the expression 'after what does not profit,' a stock way to speak of idols as useless entities.

instances.hebrew_text: וְאַחֲרֵי לֹא־יוֹעִלוּ הָלָכוּ
instances.english_text: and they went after what can do no good
target: the idols and false objects of trust the leaders pursue
vehicle: things that provide no benefit or profit
ground: lack of real efficacy or advantage
posture: deriding idols and false trusts as utterly useless
instances.explanation: Idols and false trusts are described metonymically as 'what does not profit', presenting their worthlessness in terms of economic uselessness.

deliberation: Looked for legal or martial imagery. The verb 'contend' (אָרִיב) evokes a courtroom dispute, a common covenant-lawsuit metaphor for God's dealings with Israel.

instances.hebrew_text: עֹד אָרִיב אִתְּכֶם ... וְאֶת־בְּנֵי בְנֵיכֶם אָרִיב
instances.english_text: I will go on accusing you, and I will accuse your children’s children
target: God's act of confronting Israel's unfaithfulness
vehicle: a plaintiff prosecuting a lawsuit against another party
posture: depicting God's judgment as legitimate legal action
forensic and serious, not merely emotional
instances.explanation: YHWH describes His dealing with Israel in terms of bringing a legal case against them and their descendants, invoking courtroom imagery.

deliberation: Verse consists of commands to examine distant nations; the language is literal exhortation without crafted images beyond normal 'cross over and see' idiom.
Considered 'no-gods' and 'exchanged its glory.' 'Glory' (כבודו) stands metonymically for YHWH Himself or His presence; exchanging this for 'what does not profit' continues the idol polemic.

instances.hebrew_text: וְעַמִּי הֵמִיר כְּבוֹדוֹ בְּלֹא יוֹעִיל
instances.english_text: My people has exchanged its glory for what can do no good
target: Israel's relationship with YHWH and their adoption of idols
object of national worship and trust
vehicle: glory as a designation for God’s manifest presence or honor, and 'what does not profit' for idols
ground: swapping what is supremely valuable and real for something worthless
posture: shocked condemnation of Israel's foolish exchange
instances.explanation: YHWH Himself is referred to as 'their glory', and idols as 'what does not profit'; Israel is said to have traded the one for the other.

deliberation: The heavens are summoned to react emotionally—be appalled, shudder—clearly personifying the cosmos as an astonished witness to Israel's sin.

instances.hebrew_text: שֹׁמּוּ שָׁמַיִם עַל־זֹאת וְשַׂעֲרוּ חָרְבוּ מְאֹד
instances.english_text: Be appalled, O heavens, at this; be horrified, utterly dazed
target: the reaction appropriate to Israel’s apostasy
moral and emotional response to sin
vehicle: the heavens as shocked, shuddering observers
ground: the deed is so outrageous it would shock even inanimate creation
posture: heightening the gravity of Israel’s sin by universalizing the shock
instances.explanation: The inanimate heavens are addressed as though they could experience and display horror, underscoring how appalling Israel's behavior is.

deliberation: Central, extended metaphor: YHWH as a spring of living water versus the people's self-hewn, broken cisterns. Saw this as one coherent contrast rather than separate figures.

instances.hebrew_text: אֹתִי עָזְבוּ מְקוֹר מַיִם חַיִּים לַחְצֹב לָהֶם בֹּארוֹת בֹּארֹת נִשְׁבָּרִים אֲשֶׁר לֹא־יָכִלוּ הַמָּיִם
instances.english_text: They have forsaken Me, the Fount of living waters, to hew out for themselves cisterns, broken cisterns, that cannot hold water
target: Israel's choice of idols and self-reliance over trust in YHWH
source of spiritual life and security
vehicle: a natural spring of fresh water versus cracked cisterns that leak
water sources in an arid land
ground: abandoning a reliable, life-giving source for useless, man-made substitutes
posture: indignant portrayal of Israel’s apostasy as self-sabotaging stupidity
instances.explanation: Trust in YHWH is likened to drinking from a spring of living water, while idols and political schemes are likened to broken cisterns that cannot hold water.

deliberation: The questions about Israel being a slave or home-born slave are rhetorical and metaphorical, comparing Israel's treatment by the nations to that of a permanent slave.

instances.hebrew_text: הַעֶבֶד יִשְׂרָאֵל אִם־יְלִיד בָּיִת הוּא מַדּוּעַ הָיָה לָבַז
instances.english_text: Is Israel a bondman? Is he a home-born slave? Then why is he given over to plunder?
target: Israel's oppressed condition among the nations
vehicle: a chattel or house-born slave destined for perpetual servitude and plunder
ground: being treated as property and prey, lacking freedom and honor
posture: expressing outrage that God's people are treated as if inherently slaves
instances.explanation: Israel's political subjugation is framed as though they were inherently a slave-class, which they are not, highlighting the abnormality of their plight.

deliberation: The oppressing nations are likened explicitly to young lions that roar and devastate the land—a simile with animal imagery.

instances.hebrew_text: עָלָיו יִשְׁאֲגוּ כְּפִרִים נָתְנוּ קוֹלָם
instances.english_text: Lions have roared over him, they have raised their cries
ground: ferocity, dominance, and causing terror and desolation
posture: portraying Israel as helpless prey to ruthless attackers
instances.explanation: The attacking nations are compared to roaring young lions over their prey, highlighting their ferocity and the devastation they bring.

deliberation: The phrase 'they will pasture/shear you, the crown of your head' is idiomatic; the 'head' or 'crown' stands for Israel's dignity, and the verb evokes stripping or wounding—an image of humiliation.

instances.hebrew_text: גַּם־בְּנֵי־נֹף וְתַחְפַּנְחֵס יִרְעוּךְ קׇדְקֹד
instances.english_text: Those, too, in Noph and Tahpanhes will lay bare your head (graze your crown)
target: status and protection of the people
vehicle: the crown/top of the head being grazed, shorn, or wounded
removal or injury at the most visible, honored part
ground: public humiliation and vulnerability inflicted by foreign powers
posture: warning of coming shame at the hands of Egyptian centers of power
instances.explanation: Egyptian cities are said to graze or strip Judah's 'crown', an idiom picturing national humiliation as injury to the head.

deliberation: Language is largely literal: forsaking YHWH who led them in the way (the exodus/conquest path). 'Leading in the way' is a common shepherding/travel metaphor, but here it directly recalls historical guidance. I judge it more as straightforward than as a crafted new figure.
Detected water-drinking imagery as metaphorical: 'going to Egypt/Assyria to drink the waters' stands for seeking political and military aid there.

instances.hebrew_text: מַה־לָּךְ לְדֶרֶךְ מִצְרַיִם לִשְׁתּוֹת מֵי שִׁחֹר ... לְדֶרֶךְ אַשּׁוּר לִשְׁתּוֹת מֵי נָהָר
instances.english_text: What is the good of your going to Egypt to drink the waters of the Nile, and to Assyria to drink the waters of the River?
target: Judah's search for security through foreign alliances
political dependence on Egypt and Assyria
vehicle: traveling to foreign rivers to drink their water
ground: depending on an external source for life and relief, instead of relying on YHWH
misplaced trust and thirst for help
posture: questioning and critiquing Judah’s craving for foreign support
instances.explanation: Going to 'drink' Egypt’s and Assyria’s waters is a vivid way of describing Judah’s reliance on those powers for survival and security.

deliberation: Key figure is the personification of 'your evil' and 'your apostasies' as instructors who discipline and rebuke Israel.

instances.hebrew_text: תְּיַסְּרֵךְ רָעָתֵךְ וּמְשֻׁבוֹתַיִךְ תּוֹכִחֻךְ
instances.english_text: Let your misfortune reprove you, let your afflictions rebuke you
target: the consequences of Israel's sin and apostasy
vehicle: teachers or disciplinarians who instruct and correct a wayward pupil
ground: suffering itself conveys a moral lesson and exposes wrongdoing
posture: urging Israel to read its suffering as divine instruction
instances.explanation: Israel's own evil and apostasies are personified as the ones who discipline and rebuke her through their consequences.

deliberation: Two distinct images: (1) breaking the yoke and bonds, an agrarian servitude metaphor for liberation; (2) reclining as a harlot on every high hill and under every green tree—sexual imagery for idolatry and a stereotyped cultic merism.

instances.hebrew_text: שָׁבַרְתִּי עֻלֵּךְ נִתַּקְתִּי מוֹסְרוֹתַיִךְ
instances.english_text: I broke your yoke, I tore off your yoke-bands
target: Israel's release from bondage (especially Egypt) and obligation to foreign masters
vehicle: an animal's yoke and harness being broken off
beasts of burden freed from apparatus of labor
ground: removal of controlling restraints and enforced labor
posture: reminding Israel of gracious liberation they have spurned
instances.explanation: Israel's liberation from foreign bondage is pictured as breaking the yoke and bonds off a draft animal.

instances.hebrew_text: כִּי עַל־כָּל־גִּבְעָה גְבֹהָה וְתַחַת כָּל־עֵץ רַעֲנָן אַתְּ צֹעָה זֹנָה
instances.english_text: On every high hill and under every verdant tree, you recline as a whore
target: Israel's pervasive idolatry and covenant unfaithfulness
vehicle: a prostitute lying down with multiple partners at cult sites on hills and under trees
ground: unfaithfulness, promiscuity, and indiscriminate seeking of lovers/allies
posture: sharply condemnatory, shaming Israel via sexualized imagery
instances.explanation: Idolatrous worship at hilltop shrines and sacred trees is depicted as a prostitute's actions everywhere, with 'every high hill and every green tree' forming an idiomatic merism for pervasive cultic infidelity.

deliberation: Classic vineyard metaphor: God planted Israel as a choice vine, but it turned into a degenerate foreign vine.

instances.hebrew_text: וְאָנֹכִי נְטַעְתִּיךְ שׂוֹרֵק כֻּלּוֹ זֶרַע אֱמֶת וְאֵיךְ נֶהְפַּכְתְּ לִי סוּרֵי הַגֶּפֶן נָכְרִיָּה
instances.english_text: I planted you with noble vines, all with choicest seed; how have you turned into a base, an alien vine!
target: Israel's moral and religious character and its degeneration
vehicle: a carefully planted choice grapevine that turns into a wild foreign vine
ground: expectation of good fruit from good planting versus corrupt yield
posture: expressing astonishment and grief at Israel’s corruption
instances.explanation: Israel is portrayed as a vine God planted with the best stock, which has mysteriously degenerated into an alien, inferior vine.

deliberation: Moral guilt is depicted in terms of physical dirt or stain that washing cannot remove, using cleansing agents (natron, lye) as imagery.

instances.hebrew_text: כִּי אִם־תְּכַבְּסִי בַנֶּתֶר וְתַרְבִּי־לָךְ בֹּרִית נִכְתָּם עֲוֹנֵךְ לְפָנָי
instances.english_text: Though you wash with natron and use much lye, your guilt is ingrained before Me
target: the depth and permanence of Judah's sin in God's sight
vehicle: stubborn stains that remain even after intense washing with strong cleansers
ground: impossibility of self-cleansing from deeply set impurity
posture: denying Judah's claim to be able to cleanse or hide its sin
instances.explanation: Even if Judah used the strongest cleansing agents, its iniquity would still appear as a set stain, showing the moral impossibility of self-justification.

deliberation: After denying defilement, Israel is told to consider her ways, then compared explicitly to a restless young she-camel in heat—an animal simile for frantic pursuit of idolatrous lovers.

instances.hebrew_text: בִּכְרָה קַלָּה מְשָׂרֶכֶת דְּרָכֶיהָ
instances.english_text: Like a lustful she-camel, restlessly running about
target: Israel's uncontrollable drive toward idolatry and foreign alliances
vehicle: a young female camel in heat weaving her paths
ground: unrestrained, irrational pursuit driven by desire
posture: shaming and exposing Israel’s behavior as animalistic and uncontrolled
instances.explanation: Israel's idolatrous conduct is likened to a young she-camel darting to and fro in heat, emphasizing desperation and lack of restraint.

deliberation: Continues and extends the animal imagery with a wild donkey accustomed to the desert, sniffing the wind in her craving. This is a metaphor (not introduced with 'like' in Hebrew) for unrestrained lust for idols/lovers.

instances.hebrew_text: פֶּרֶה לִמֻּד מִדְבָּר בְּאַוַּת נַפְשָׁהּ שָׁאֲפָה רוּחַ תַּאֲנָתָהּ מִי יְשִׁיבֶנָּה כָּל־מְבַקְשֶׁיהָ לֹא יִיעָפוּ בְּחָדְשָׁהּ יִמְצָאוּנְהָ
instances.english_text: A wild ass used to the desert, snuffing the wind in her eagerness; whose passion none can restrain. None that seek her need grow weary; in her season they will find her
target: Judah's driven, shameless pursuit of idolatrous or political 'lovers'
vehicle: a wild female donkey in heat tracking and advertising her scent so that any male will easily find her
ground: insatiable desire, lack of restraint, and easy availability to many partners
promiscuity and eagerness for illicit unions
posture: intentionally graphic and humiliating to indict Judah’s unfaithfulness
instances.explanation: Judah is portrayed as a wild donkey in heat, whose cravings cannot be restrained and who is easily found by any suitor, capturing the intensity and shamelessness of her idolatry.

deliberation: Advice to keep the foot from going bare and the throat from thirst is metaphorical, warning against exhausting pursuit of foreign 'lovers'; the declaration 'I love strangers, after them I will go' continues the adultery motif.

instances.hebrew_text: מִנְעִי רַגְלֵךְ מִיָּחֵף וּגְרוֹנֵךְ מִצִּמְאָה ... כִּי־אָהַבְתִּי זָרִים וְאַחֲרֵיהֶם אֵלֵךְ
instances.english_text: Save your foot from going bare, and your throat from thirst. But you say: It is no use, for I love strangers, and after them I will go
target: Judah's self-destructive efforts to pursue alliances/idols
political and spiritual seeking of foreign powers
vehicle: a woman wearing out her feet and parching her throat chasing after lovers
physical exhaustion in pursuit of relationships
ground: costly, exhausting pursuit of illicit attachments
posture: admonishing Judah to stop, but exposing her obstinate love for outsiders
instances.explanation: Physical images of bare feet and a thirsty throat portray the effort expended in chasing foreign lovers, symbolizing Judah's relentless pursuit of idols and alliances.

deliberation: Clear simile: the shame of the house of Israel and its leaders is likened to the disgrace of a thief caught in the act.

instances.hebrew_text: כְּבֹשֶׁת גַּנָּב כִּי יִמָּצֵא כֵּן הֹבִישׁוּ בֵּית יִשְׂרָאֵל
instances.english_text: Like a thief chagrined when caught, so is the House of Israel chagrined
target: Israel's exposed guilt and shame before God
vehicle: a thief discovered and put to shame
ground: sudden exposure of hidden guilt leading to public shame
posture: highlighting the legitimacy of Israel's shame
instances.explanation: Israel's embarrassment at being exposed in sin is compared to a thief's shame when caught.

deliberation: Two distinct figures: (1) idols of wood and stone addressed as father/mother—a mix of personification and parental metaphor; (2) turning 'back' not 'face' to YHWH, a spatial metaphor for rejection.

instances.hebrew_text: אֹמְרִים לָעֵץ אָבִי אַתָּה וְלָאֶבֶן אַתְּ יְלִדְתָּנוּ
instances.english_text: They say to wood, You are my father, and to stone, You gave birth to us
target: Israel's attribution of origin and care to idols
vehicle: children addressing their parents who begot them
ground: assigning life-giving, protective roles to idols that truly belong to God
posture: mocking and exposing the absurdity and blasphemy of such claims
instances.explanation: Inanimate wooden and stone idols are personified and addressed as parents, showing how Israel wrongly credits them with its origin and care.

instances.hebrew_text: כִּי־פָנוּ אֵלַי עֹרֶף וְלֹא פָנִים
instances.english_text: For they turned to Me the back and not the face
target: Israel's relational stance toward God (rejection vs. openness)
vehicle: turning one’s back on someone instead of one’s face
ground: turning away signifies rejection and refusal of relationship
posture: accusing Israel of deliberate, contemptuous rejection of YHWH
instances.explanation: Facing someone symbolizes openness and relationship; turning the back symbolizes rejection. Israel is said to have literally oriented away from God in this metaphor.

deliberation: The main figure is biting irony: the idols are told to arise and save, which they cannot. Also, 'gods as many as your towns' may be literal or slightly hyperbolic; the irony about their impotence is the clearest device.

instances.hebrew_text: יָקֻמוּ אִם־יוֹשִׁיעוּךָ בְּעֵת רָעָתֶךָ
instances.english_text: Let them arise and save you, if they can, in your hour of calamity
target: the alleged power of Judah's handmade gods
vehicle: inert statues being commanded to get up and deliver
human-like saviors responding to a summons
ground: expected ability to act versus actual impotence
contrast between claimed help and real inability
posture: taunting and exposing the futility of trusting idols
instances.explanation: The command for the idols to 'arise and save' is ironic, since they cannot move or help; their impotence undercuts Judah’s trust in them.

deliberation: The verb 'contend' (תריבו) again invokes legal disputation—God depicted as the defendant or plaintiff in a courtroom where Israel tries to bring a case. This continues the covenant-lawsuit metaphor.

instances.hebrew_text: לָמָּה תָרִיבוּ אֵלָי
instances.english_text: Why do you call Me to account? (Why do you contend with Me?)
target: Israel's attempts to challenge or blame God
vehicle: litigants bringing a lawsuit against someone
ground: accusing and arguing as if God were at fault
posture: rebuking Israel's presumptuous prosecution of God
instances.explanation: Israel's complaints are likened to bringing a legal case against God, extending the covenant-lawsuit imagery.

deliberation: Key figure: 'your sword has devoured your prophets like a destroying lion'—personification of the sword as an eater and a simile to a ravenous lion.

instances.hebrew_text: אָכְלָה חַרְבְּכֶם נְבִיאֵיכֶם כְּאַרְיֵה מַשְׁחִית
instances.english_text: Your sword has devoured your prophets like a ravening lion
target: the killing of prophets by the people (or their rulers)
vehicle: a lion devouring prey, and a sword that 'eats'
ground: complete, violent destruction as if swallowed by a beast
ferocity and finality of the killings
posture: condemning the people for brutal suppression of prophets
instances.explanation: The people's sword is said to 'devour' prophets, and this devouring is compared to a destroying lion, emphasizing the savage nature of their violence.

deliberation: God asks whether He has been 'a desert' or 'a land of deep gloom' to Israel—metaphors for harshness and deprivation, contrasting with His true beneficence.

instances.hebrew_text: הֲמִדְבָּר הָיִיתִי לְיִשְׂרָאֵל אִם אֶרֶץ מַאְפֵּלְיָה
instances.english_text: Have I been like a desert to Israel, or a land of deep gloom?
target: God's character and treatment of Israel
vehicle: a desert or land of thick darkness where there is no provision or light
ground: privation, danger, and hopelessness versus care and provision
whether God has been life-giving or life-denying
posture: challenging Israel's false perception of God as harsh or restrictive
instances.explanation: God uses images of a desert and a dark land to ask whether He has treated Israel that way, implying that He has actually been the opposite.

deliberation: Draws an analogy between a maiden/ bride forgetting her adornments and Israel forgetting God—functionally a simile, though without 'like' in Hebrew, emphasizing the unnaturalness of such forgetfulness.

instances.hebrew_text: הֲתִשְׁכַּח בְּתוּלָה עֶדְיָהּ כַּלָּה קִשֻּׁרֶיהָ וְעַמִּי שְׁכֵחוּנִי יָמִים אֵין מִסְפָּר
instances.english_text: Can a maiden forget her jewels, a bride her adornments? Yet My people have forgotten Me—days without number
target: Israel's persistent neglect and disregard of YHWH
vehicle: a young woman or bride forgetting her ornaments on her wedding day
ground: it is virtually unthinkable to forget what is most precious and identity-defining
posture: expressing astonishment and reproach at Israel’s forgetfulness
instances.explanation: Just as it is unthinkable for a bride to forget her wedding adornments, so it is unnatural and shocking that Israel has forgotten God for countless days.

deliberation: Saw an extended seduction metaphor: 'beautifying your way to seek love' and 'teaching even wicked women your ways' portray Judah's scheming for illicit relationships as a woman's cosmetic and instructional arts of seduction.

instances.hebrew_text: מַה־תֵּיטִבִי דַרְכֵּךְ לְבַקֵּשׁ אַהֲבָה לָכֵן גַּם אֶת־הָרָעוֹת לִמַּדְתְּ אֶת־דְּרָכָיִךְ
instances.english_text: How skillfully you plan your way to seek out love! Therefore you have even taught the worst of women your ways
target: Judah's calculated pursuit of idolatrous or political liaisons
strategies for alliances and idol worship
vehicle: a woman artfully adorning and managing her behavior to attract lovers, even becoming a teacher to other immoral women
ground: deliberate, refined skill in gaining illicit partners, surpassing even notorious sinners
posture: sarcastic condemnation of Judah as more adept in evil than others
instances.explanation: Judah's policies and idolatries are portrayed as a woman's perfected arts of seduction, so advanced that even wicked women could learn from her.

deliberation: Examined 'on your skirts/wings is found the blood' as metaphor for visible evidence of murder. Skirts/wings (כְּנָפַיִךְ) stand for garments, which here bear incriminating blood of the innocent poor.

instances.hebrew_text: גַּם בִּכְנָפַיִךְ נִמְצְאוּ דַּם נַפְשׁוֹת אֶבְיוֹנִים נְקִיִּים
instances.english_text: Moreover, on your garments (skirts) is found the lifeblood of the innocent poor
target: Judah's culpability in shedding innocent blood, especially of the poor
vehicle: blood stains found on the edges of garments
visible traces of murder on clothing
ground: clear, incriminating evidence clinging to the person
posture: exposing Judah's hidden crimes as if physically evident
instances.explanation: The image of blood on the skirts of garments depicts Judah as literally marked by the blood of the innocent, making her guilt visible and undeniable.

deliberation: Main figurative element: 'I will enter into judgment with you' uses legal proceedings as a metaphor for God's response to Judah's claim of innocence.

instances.hebrew_text: הִנְנִי נִשְׁפָּט אוֹתָךְ עַל־אׇמְרֵךְ לֹא חָטָאתִי
instances.english_text: Lo, I will bring you to judgment for saying, I have not sinned
target: God's act of confronting and condemning Judah’s denial of sin
vehicle: entering into a judicial process, trying a case in court
ground: authoritative, structured evaluation of claims and pronouncement of guilt
exposure of false plea of innocence
posture: asserting God's right to legally challenge Judah’s self-acquittal
instances.explanation: God depicts His response to Judah’s claim of innocence as a legal trial, underscoring the seriousness of their denial.

deliberation: The verse continues the 'changing ways for lovers' theme: 'How you cheapen yourself by changing your course!' evokes prostitution imagery for shifting political loyalties; shame through Egypt as with Assyria is literal outcome but colored by this metaphor.

instances.hebrew_text: מַה־תֵּזְלִי מְאֹד לְשַׁנּוֹת אֶת־דַּרְכֵּךְ
instances.english_text: How you cheapen yourself, by changing your course!
target: Judah's frequent shifts in political and religious allegiance
vehicle: a person becoming cheap or light (morally) by constantly changing paths, like a promiscuous lover
loss of worth through instability and promiscuity
ground: instability and readiness to sell oneself lower and lower
posture: rebuking Judah for self-devaluation through restless alliance-seeking
instances.explanation: Judah’s continual changing of 'way' or course is depicted as cheapening herself, echoing the prostitution metaphor for her foreign entanglements.

deliberation: Key idiom: 'you will go out with your hands on your head'—a gesture of mourning or captivity, symbolizing complete defeat. Also, 'your trusts' stands for the allies/idols rejected by God (metonymy).

instances.hebrew_text: וְיָדַיִךְ עַל־רֹאשֵׁךְ כִּי־מָאַס יְהוָה בְּמִבְטַחַיִךְ
instances.english_text: You will come out with your hands on your head, for the LORD has rejected those you trust
target: Judah's future state of humiliation and loss when alliances fail
vehicle: a person leaving with hands on the head in a mourning or captive posture
public gesture of despair and subjugation
ground: visible acknowledgment of disaster and powerlessness
humiliation and grief over failed hopes
posture: forewarning Judah of utter disappointment in her false trusts
instances.explanation: The idiom of going out with hands on the head portrays Judah's future as one of mourning or captivity when the objects of her trust, rejected by God, fail her.
